subject: RE: [junit] problem making TestCases.
msgSnippet: Saleem, First off, test methods need to be public void and start with the word test ( i.e. testMyMethodOne(), testMyMethodTwo() ).  Second, it is unclear
messageBody:
Saleem,

First off, test methods need to be 'public void' and start with the word
"test" ( i.e. testMyMethodOne(), testMyMethodTwo() ). Second, it is unclear
to me whether or not connecting to the Directory Server is what you want to
do. How hard would it be for you to use mock objects? I assume you have
objects that wrap the connections and polls/pushes to the Server...

-Jason

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Saleem Shah Khan [mailto:saleemsk@...]
> Sent: Thursday, July 26, 2001 10:08 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] problem making TestCases.
>
>
> Hello All,
>
> I am new to unit testing. I am usint junit
> framework for testing. I think i am little bit
> confused while creating the testcases. Actually the
> problem is that, in my programe, i am using Directory
> Server as data repository, but i am not sure how to
> make the testcase. Should my Testcase needs to connect
> to Directory server for testing or what. I just
> coppied one of my method as an examples, may be one of
> you can help me.
>
> Thanks,
> Shah Khan.
>
> P.S. Here is my simple method code.
>
> public int bind() throws StorageException {
>
> CurrentUser user = new
> CurrentUser(bindDn,passwd,host,Integer.parseInt(port),"","true");
> ldap = new LdapAPI(user);
> try {
> if (ldap != null) {
> // bind to directory
> ldap.bind(user.host, new
> Integer(user.port).toString(), user.DN, user.passwd,
> "");
> // bind for authentification and
> common config data
> try {
> ac = new
> authConfig(authConfigBase,user);
> cc = new
> comConfig(commonConfigBase,user);
> return NO_ERROR;
> }
> catch (DirectoryException e) {
> log.error("bind: "+e.toString())
> ;
> return ERROR_CONNECTION;
> }
>
> }
> else {
> log.error("Error in LdapAPI
> connection ") ;
> return ERROR_CONNECTION;
> }
> } catch (NamingException e) {
> log.error("bind: "+e.toString()) ;
> return ERROR_CONNECTION;
> } catch (Exception e) {
> log.error("bind: "+e.toString()) ;
> return ERROR_CONNECTION;
> }
> }
>
